Detailed Description

PPP Channel Class

This class implements a TCP/IP stack that allows an iOS device to communicate with an Companion terminal using TCP/IP over PPP on a serial link.
To initialize the ICPPP object, do as following:

  • Instantiate the object by calling ICPPP_sharedChannel. The returned instance has to be retained since this method returns an auto-released object.
  • Set the ICPPPDelegateProperty property to a valid object that will receive the events of the class


After the ICPPP object is initialized, the TCP/IP stack can be started by calling ICPPP_openChannel. This action will trigger a PPP connection to the terminal, after which the TCP/IP communication between the terminal and the iOS device becomes ready.
ICPPP offers networking functionalities that can not be achieved with ICNetwork. These include:

  • Allow the terminal to open up to 5 simultaneously TCP connections to remote hosts (ICPPP can be configured to support more than that number)
  • Accept incoming connections and map them to ports on which some terminal applications are listening. In this configuration the terminal behaves as a server and the iOS device as a gateway.
  • Allow the terminal to open TCP connections as a client to the iOS device

Method Documentation

- (void) addiOSToTerminalBridgeLocalOnPort: (NSInteger)  port

Adds a TCP bridge from the terminal to the iOS device for the provided port number. The listen is done only on localhost.

Call this function when you need to connect the terminal to a server running on the iOS device. This function will map the incoming terminal connection on the ICPPP stack for the provided port, to the same port of a server running on the native iOS network stack. Call this function after opening the ICPPP channel.

This function is useful if an iOS application wants to communicate in TCP with the terminal in the configuration where the terminal is the client, and the iOS device is the server.

Bridges added by calling addiOSToTerminalBridgeOnPort, addTerminalToiOSBridgeOnPort and addiOSToTerminalBridgeLocalOnPort are limited to 12. This means that these functions should not be called more than 12 times.
A bridge remains active until the ICPPP channel is closed and won't be started automatically when the channel is opened again. It is necessary in this case to re-create it when needed.

- (void) addiOSToTerminalBridgeOnPort: (NSInteger)  port

Adds a TCP bridge from the terminal to the iOS device for the provided port number.

Call this function when you need to connect the terminal to a server running on the iOS device. This function will map the incoming terminal connection on the ICPPP stack for the provided port, to the same port of a server running on the native iOS network stack. Call this function after opening the ICPPP channel.

This function is useful if an iOS application wants to communicate in TCP with the terminal in the configuration where the terminal is the client, and the iOS device is the server.

Bridges added by calling addiOSToTerminalBridgeOnPort, addTerminalToiOSBridgeOnPort and addiOSToTerminalBridgeLocalOnPort are limited to 12. This means that these functions should not be called more than 12 times.
A bridge remains active until the ICPPP channel is closed and won't be started automatically when the channel is opened again. It is necessary in this case to re-create it when needed.

- (void) addTerminalToiOSBridgeOnPort: (NSInteger)  port

Adds a TCP bridge from the iOS device to terminal for the provided port number.

Call this function when you need to connect your iOS device to a server running on the terminal. This function will map the incoming connection requests arriving on the native iOS network stack for the provided port, to the same port of a server running on the terminal side. Call this function after opening the ICPPP channel.

This function is useful if an iOS application wants to communicate in TCP with the terminal in the configuration where the terminal is the server, and the iOS device is the client. This works the same as the port mapping mechanism used on routers. The connection requests can originate from a local or remote client.

Bridges added by calling addiOSToTerminalBridgeOnPort, addTerminalToiOSBridgeOnPort and addiOSToTerminalBridgeLocalOnPort are limited to 12. This means that these functions should not be called more than 12 times.
A bridge remains active until the ICPPP channel is closed and won't be started automatically when the channel is opened again. It is necessary in this case to re-create it when needed.

- (void) closeChannel

Close the ICPPP channel.

This method disconnects the PPP link and cuts any TCP communication going between the iOS device the terminal.

- (iSMPResult) openChannel

Open the ICPPP channel.

This method opens the ICPPP channel, which will put in place a TCP/IP over PPP communication between the payment terminal and the iOS device.
This method returns immediately, while the PPP link takes time to be established. That's why, the calling application must until the pppChannelDidOpen callback is fired before being able to perform TCP communication with the terminal. When the channel opens and becomes ready, the application can get the attributes of the PPP connection. Those can be retrieved using the following properties:

  • IP : IP address of iOS device
  • submask : Submask of the network
  • dns : IP address of the DNS server when available
  • terminalIP : IP address of the terminal

These attributes are not necessary for the the app to communicate with the terminal. They are just provided for information.

Returns
An integer constant defined with the eISMPResult enumeration. ISMP_Result_SUCCESS on success.
+ (ICPPP *) sharedChannel

Returns the unique shared instance of ICPPP.

The object returned by this method is autoreleased and must be retained to stay alive.

Returns
A pointer to the shared instance

Property Documentation

- (id<ICISMPDeviceDelegate, ICPPPDelegate>) delegate
readwritenonatomicassign

The delegate of an ICPPP object.

This property should be assigned the reference of a delegate object that will receive the events of ICPPP - This object should implement the ICISMPDeviceDelegate and ICPPPDelegate protocols

- (NSString*) dns
readnonatomicassign

The IP address of the DNS server to be used inside the sub-network created between the iOS device and the terminal.

This is the IP address of the DNS server to be used inside the sub-network created between the iOS device and the terminal after opening the ICPPP channel. This property becomes available after the event pppChannelDidOpen is fired.

- (NSString*) IP
readnonatomicassign

The IP address attributed to the iOS device when connected to the terminal using ICPPP.

This is the IP address obtained by the iOS device after it connects to the terminal using ICPPP. This property becomes available after the event pppChannelDidOpen is fired.

- (NSString*) submask
readnonatomicassign

The mask of the sub-network created between the iOS device and the terminal.

This is the mask of the sub-network created between the iOS device and the terminal after opening the ICPPP channel. This property becomes available after the event pppChannelDidOpen is fired.

- (NSString*) terminalIP
readnonatomicassign

The IP address of the terminal when connected to the iOS device using ICPPP.

This is the IP address obtained by the terminal after it connects to the iOS device after opening the ICPPP channel. This property becomes available after the event pppChannelDidOpen is fired.
